listDisplay.secondary: The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writin...
listDisplay.expandedContent:
The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writing
                and the calendar, master of medicine and learning. Depicted as a wise, aged man or as a great cosmic
                caiman, he dwells in the highest of the thirteen heavens and is the father of countless gods. With
                his consort Ixchel, he presides over creation, knowledge, and the healing arts that sustain humanity.

name: Maya - Itzamna

periods.description: Emergence of creator god concept in Maya religion
Fully developed as supreme creator and patron of writing/calendar
Continued importance, adapted by Postclassic Maya city-states

calendarAssociations.significance: Master of calendar system - essential to Maya civilization

codexAssociations.glyph: Itzamna glyph appears in Dresden, Paris, Madrid codices
codexAssociations.writing: Patron of scribes and calendar priests
codexAssociations.astronomical: Linked to Venus morning star and solar cycles

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
